elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: INT. GARRET
SCRATCHING OF PAPER AND PEN AS FLINT WRITES.
Agent Funken, berichte - Ware ist abgeholt. (GERMAN CONTINUES AND FADES UNDER TRANSLATION) Abteilung sieben null neun gefahrdet. Weitere Informationen folgen.
[NB: FLINT IS FLUENT IN GERMAN, BUT NOT A NATIVE SPEAKER.
Agg-ent funka, barik-ta — Varrer ist ap-ge-holt. Ap-tie-lung zee-ben null nyn ge-fair-det.
Vie-terra infor-mat-zee-onen foll-gun. ]
(OVERLAID OVER PREVIOUS) ‘Agent Spark reporting. Goods have been picked up. Division seven oh-nine compromised. More information to follow.’
CLICKING OF ENIGMA CIPHER MACHINE, SETTING ROTORS, PRESSING KEYS.
Now then. Rotors set. (USING CIPHER, TAPS KEY, WRITES DOWN EACH LETTER) G. K. T. I. (FADES UNDER FOLLOWING RADIO MORSE TRANSMISSION) S. V. E. J. T. G. A...
TUNES HIS RADIO AND STARTS USING MORSE TRANSMITTER.
CODE BEGINS TRANSMITTING THROUGH THE ETHER — DOTS AND
DASH-DASH-DOT, DASH-DOT-DASH, DASH, DOT-DOT, DOT-DOT- DOT, DOT-DOT-DOT-DASH, DOT, DOT-DASH-DASH-DASH, DASH, DASH- DASH-DOT, DOT-DASH.
SCENE 2: INT. RECEIVER ROOM, STATION Y [FX ONLY]
RADIO-RECEIVING STATION. KEYS TAPPING, PHONES RINGING. LOW
CONVERSATION.
A CRACKLING RADIO SIGNAL TUNES INTO THE SAME MORSE CODE TRANSMITTED IN SCENE 1.
CROSS-FADE TO:
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 3
SCENE 3: EXT. ROAD OUTSIDE BLETCHLEY
DRIVING ALONG ROAD. IT PULLS UP ON GRAVEL DRIVEWAY, LOTS OF PEOPLE BUSTLING PAST. SOLDIER OPENS GATE.
RUNS OVER.
(CALLING) Hello there!
PULLS INTO DRIVE, STOPS ENGINE. RIDER UNLOCKS SATCHEL AND
PACKAGE AS SYLVIA ARRIVES.
Morning Miss.
How was it this morning?
Not too busy till I got over here.
Always the way!
(HANDING OVER PACKAGE) Here we are. Latest despatches from the Y-Stations. Sign here, miss.
SIGNS.
Thank you. They’1ll be looked at right away.
See you later, Miss. Back this afternoon.
ENGINE.
(CALLING) Goodbye! Drive safely!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 4
SCENE 4: INT. HUT TWELVE-A
FADE UP B/G NOISE OF BOMBE MACHINE (RATTLING, HAMMERING AND WHIRRING OF LARGE INDUSTRIAL-SIZED DECODING MACHINE) IN ANOTHER ROOM.
IN THIS ROOM, HALF A DOZEN AGENTS USE CLICKING, TYPEX DECODING MACHINES, SCRATCHING PENS AND TYPWRITERS.
(CLOSE) V- E—J-T-—G-A. That’s.. (USING TYPEX MACHINE) ‘F —U-—N-—K-—E -N. (BEAT) Spark! (CALLING) Doctor! Doctor Smith!
(WALKING OVER) Yes, Miss Wimpole?
I’ve another communication from Agent Spark.
Excellent work, young lady. Cross reference with the daily logs in C Block, I’1ll review them all together. Here. I’ve a few more for you to go through.
LARGE PILE OF PAPERS ON SYLVIA’S DESK.
(DEFLATED) Yes sir. Thank you sir.
(WALKING OUT) I’1ll be in my office up at the Main House. (STOPS AT DOOR. SATISFIED SIGH, TO SELF) Ah, Bletchley Park. (TO ROOM) Keep up the good work. All of you!
THEME.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 5: INT. WAVENDON HOUSE DORM.
ENTERS, RINGING A BELL.
Wakey, wakey. Rise and shine, ladies.
WAKING AND GETTING UP.
Now. Morning shift. Page and Wimpole. Seagrove and Bailey. Bombe duty. Hut 11. The rest of you, Hut 12-A with me. Cribs and translation.
RUSH ABOUT GETTING READY.
Quick as you like. Get to it now.
WALKS THROUGH BUSTLING DORM.
(OVER ACTIVITY) Come along. Fill your basins. Quick wash and
brush up. Uniforms on. (BEAT) Wimpole? Where’s Wren Wimpole?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 6: INT. WAVENDON HOUSE WASHROOM
TAP INTO BATHTUB. SYLVIA SOBBING. CONSTANCE OPENS DOOR
AND ENTERS.
SOBS
(APPROACHING) Wren Wimpole. Others would like to use the facilities.
(SOBS) I’m sorry, ma’am. I’m so sorry.
Look at you. You’re exhausted.
I’m sorry...
When did you come off shift?
I didn’t. Not since... the night before last.
What? Three shifts in succession? Which detail were you on?
Hut Twelve-A. Special duties. Doctor Smith.
No, no, no. This won’t do. This won’t do at all. (TO SYLVIA) and dressed and into uniform at the double, Wren Wimpole. I shall see about this.
MUSIC CUT TO:
Up
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 7: INT. STAIRS, BLETCHLEY MANSION
MARCHING UP STAIRS CORRIDOR. SYLVIA SCURRYING BESIDE.
I won’t have it. Taking advantage of my girls.
(HURRYING TO KEEP UP) Please ma’am. I’m feeling better now.
Dr Smith might be new here, but he’s got to learn the rules. No double shifts. No more than two overnights a week.
I thought I’d be all right. I didn’t want to let him down.
You’ve let no-one down, Miss Wimpole. These gentlemen are not all men of the world. Sometimes they need lessons in how to deal with... people.
THEY REACH TOP OF STAIRS AND MARCH ALONG CORRIDOR.
This way. He’s taken an office along from Mr Travis, hasn’t he?
They’re so driven. In a world of their own sometimes. I don’t think he meant any harm-
(OVER HER) We put up with their eccentricities because they are geniuses. But there’s no excuse for thoughtlessness. None at all.
He keeps some kind of ‘police box’ in his room. It took a dozen chaps to get it up the stairs when he arrived.
(STOPPING) So I’ve heard. A small peculiarity compared with some of the other boffins, but another indulgence nonetheless. Here we are.
RAPS ANGRILY ON THE DOOR.
(INSIDE) One moment please!
I’m sorry to cause any trouble.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 8
It’s no trouble at all. Wait out here, Sylvia. I’11 deal with this.
KNOCKS AGAIN.
(INSIDE) All right, all right. Come in!
OPENS DOOR.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 8: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY MANSION
CONTINUOUS
SLAMMING THE DOOR. DOCTOR IS DISTRACTED, FIDDLING WITH RADIO EQUIPMENT.
This is simply not good enough. I need to lay down some ground rules. Sir.
I’1ll be right with you, Miss, um..?
Mrs Clarke. Constance Clarke. Leading WREN at Wavendon House.
Yes... And?
Any extra-ordinary use of my charges must be passed through me.
PUTS DOWN RADIO EQUIPMENT AND PAYS ATTENTION AT LAST.
‘Extra-ordinary use’..? I’m sorry? What’s this about? I am rather busy.
Wren Wimpole. She’s in floods of tears and on the brink of collapse!
Oh. Miss Wimpole? She’s been doing sterling work. A very intelligent girl.
Yes. She is a girl. You’d do well to remember that. Not a machine. She needs rest!
Oh, poor Sylvia. Things rather ran away... I’m afraid my need for information was rather urgent.
So is my Wrens’ need for sleep. How can they do their jobs properly if they are exhausted? You boffins sometimes forget. My ladies are not simply tools. They are human beings!
Sylvia has shown a particular aptitude. Her code-breaking skills are second to none.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 10
She was a mathematical prodigy at Cambridge. Commander Travis fast-tracked her through the Pro-Wren Training.
Which is why she is so useful to me!
It is not all for your benefit, Doctor Smith. Bletchley is bigger than Hut 12-A. We must all pull together. We must share resources. It is simply not fair if those resources are exhausted by you.
My, my. I can see I have a fight on my hands. Constance, was as ty
Kindly address me as Leading Wren Clarke.
I’m not with the military. I see people as more than their rank.
Mrs Clarke then, if you must.
Mrs Clarke. I apologise. Unreservedly. Might I be permitted to come to you directly in future?
Certainly. If we all abide by the proper channels, the work will be more efficiently performed.
Allow me a word of explanation.
Dr Smith?
There is a particular reason. A particular urgency to the messages I am tracking. Most secret and most important.
Secret? Everything that goes on here is secret.
This is even more secret than that. And I would welcome your assistance.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 11
Go on.
There are certain phrases. Key words I need to watch for. I’ve followed every mention of ‘golden eggs’, and they seem to coincide with a particular agent’s movements.
Who?
Agent Spark.
(RECOGNISING NAME) Spark, you say?
Yes. Anything related to him. Or golden eggs. I’d appreciate it if you could have your ladies look out and keep me informed.
(HIDING RECOGNITION) Agent Spark... Yes. Yes, of course, Dr Smith. Any assistance I can provide. Within reason.
Within reason. Thank you, Mrs Clarke. It’s good to have you on board.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 9: INT. COUNTRY CHATEAU, FRANCE
WALKS OVER FLOORBOARDS, POURS HIMSELF WINE. FOOTSTEPS AS
ENTERS.
Ah. (ACROSS ROOM) The Chateau neuf’s a bit on the vinegary side this year.
You are enjoying our hospitality I see...
Dr Schwartzmann. Only what I deserve, ain’t it?
You’ve done well so far, Agent Spark.
Please. Call me Robbie. Or Mr Flint. We’re on good enough terms. I call you Dr Schwartzman after all.
You are not so stupid to think this is my real name?
(DARK) Don’t call me stupid.
No. I know you better than that. Perhaps I chose the wrong word. Please. Mr Flint. Be seated.
You've another job for me?
You have proved your worth, since we extracted you from the Paris penitentiary.
It was a fit-up. I never robbed no-one. All the Frenchies’ misunderstanding. Couldn’t speak the lingo back before the war, you see.
Whereas now you are fluent in several.
I get by.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 13

No. Since we took control of the city and commuted your sentence, your time here at the chateau has been a good investment. Languages. Combat. Radio technique. You operate our cipher machines with skill. And of course, you have a talent with explosives.
Had a head start on that. Used to be the best safe-cracker in Bermondsey back in the thirties. You want a box opening, you come to Robbie Flint.
Your criminal past is behind you. You serve the Reich now.
Got to admit. Mr Hitler’s treated me better than any beak in Blighty.
Kindly do not refer to the Fuhrer in such casual terms.
Sorry, Dr Schwartzmann. No disrespect meant.
As I say. Your explosives expertise will be useful in your next
mission.
Going on a trip, am I?
I am arranging passage. You remember your parachute training?
Like falling off a log.
Good. But this time, you will not be going alone.
Oh.
(CALLING) Mr van Nyman?
ENTERS
Ah, right. The Dutchman.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 14
Hello Mr Flint. I’ve heard a lot about you.
Get to know one another. Very soon, you will rely on each other to stay alive.
(SHAKING HANDS) Nice to meet you, Dutch.
We expect to drop you in within the month. Rest. Prepare. I
shall send a message when your means of entry is ready.
We'll be waiting. Drop of the old vino, Dutch?
A good idea, Mr Flint.
POURS ANOTHER GLASS OF WINE.
Do not let me down. Germany expects.
MUSIC SEGUE: PASSAGE OF TIME.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 15
SCENE 10: EXT. BLETCHLEY
‘CAMPUS’ ATMOS B/G. VEHICLES PULLING UP. MARCHING TROOPS IN GROUNDS. WRENS WATCHING, WHISPERING. CONSTANCE OPENS DOORS OF MAIN BUILDING.
(EXITING BUILDING, CALLING) So this where you all are. Come along ladies. Teatime is over.
We just wanted to see what the fuss was all about.
APPROACHES.
There is no ‘fuss’. Simply a detachment from Whitehall visiting the Mansion. No need to stand and gawp. I’m sure they can get on without an audience. Off you go now.
Yes ma’am. Sorry ma’am.
SYLVIA AND OTHER WRENS MOVE OFF.
(APPROACHING) Leading Wren Clarke?
Yes, sir!
Good. I recognise you from your file. Major Harris.
Good afternoon, Major Harris, sir. (WORRIED) My... file?
See to it the staff carry on as normal. I want to minimise any disruption. The offices are in there?
Yes, sir. I’m afraid Director Travis was called to London.
I know. I’m carrying out certain tasks on behalf of Military Intelligence in the old man’s absence.
Military Intelligence? Is this to do with the new radio mast?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 16
This has no connection with Mr Churchill’s plans. Whatever they may be. The Prime Minister’s strategy is underway under the auspice of...?
Colonel Chambers is overseeing the installation.
You will be informed of your role when the time comes, I’m sure.
Yes sir.
In the meantime. I am here for a rather different duty. (CHECKS PAPERS) Hut Twelve-A. Your group’s been working there? For Smith?
Yes. My girls are on rotation along with Leading Wrens Huxtable, Mason, and Foster’s ladies. We’re all stationed over at Wavendon House.
Good. Director Travis has placed rooms in Block G at my disposal. While he’s away, I have authority. My men have already started interviews with your people.
Might I ask why-
You know better than that, Wren Clarke.
Of course, sir. Sorry, sir.
The senior staff I will question myself. (BEAT) So. That includes you. You’re free for half an hour?
Me? Now, sir?
No time like the present, eh? Follow me.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 11: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
THROUGH MESSAGES.
You’ve done well, Sylvia. Very well indeed.
LOOKS AT PAPERS.
Agent Spark has appeared with increased regularity the past few weeks. No more mention of golden eggs though.
Any clue we can get. Any clue at all. And I might not be so... stuck.
Stuck?
Believe it or not, Miss Wimpole. It was not my intention to stay here so long. I never normally do. And I usually avoid displaying too prominent a profile.
They say your evening wear was somewhat... colourful when you arrived.

It sometimes pays to blend in. This time, however, I’ve been left with no choice. Left with nothing, except for sifting through these ciphers. (SOTTO) While my poor old Ship’s as dead as a dodo, that is...
Sir?
Don’t mind me, Miss Wimpole. Routine engenders melancholy. I’m simply looking for an escape.
Escape... from what, sir?
From history.
PAPERS ONTO DESK.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 12: INT. INTERROGATION ROOM, BLOCK G
WRITES NOTES THROUGHOUT.
Nyasaland eh? They’ve been trying to shake off colonial rule for years.
They didn’t give us any trouble. My father was happy there. Until... the end.
(CHECKING PAPERS) Ah, yes. Tuberculosis — that’s what did for him, eh?
It was a difficult time. But we got through it. I was still young. I returned to London when my father passed. Completed my schooling. You know the rest.

Somerville. Modern languages... et cetera, et cetera. (LOOKS UP) You can relax, Mrs Clarke. No more questions. Four years at Bletchley Park. You’ve seen a lot, I imagine. I’m sure for you, this will all be routine.
Yes sir. Of course sir. (BEAT) Have I answered everything to your satisfaction?
All seems to be in order, yes... One more thing. Is the code-name ‘Agent Spark’ familiar to you?
I’m aware of his activities. (BEAT) Dr Smith has a special interest in him.
(MAKING A NOTE) I see.
So you’re looking for someone with a particular connection?
Curiosity. That’s something noted on your file. Capability too.
Forgive me, but... you’re here for a reason, Major Harris. If I can help, I’d like to.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 19
It’s no great secret to tell you that... someone’s credentials have been questioned. More than that, I cannot say.
I shan’t pry. (BEAT) You are party to lots of information, I imagine.
Mrs Clarke?
My... husband.
(CHECKING FILE) Lieutenant Commander Henry Clarke. Naval Intelligence. Posted to special duties last November.
You see, I haven’t heard a thing since the start of the year.
If he’s working under cover...
He’d send a note. Something. Just to let me know he’s still alive.
Depending on his circumstances, that might not be possible.
But what if his circumstances are... fatal?
I’m afraid I can offer you nothing new Mrs Clarke. Not at present.
Thank you sir. I’m sorry sir. I just had to ask.
I understand. The War requires sacrifices from us all. But we mustn’t forget, we’re still human.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 13: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
SPREADS PAPERS OVER DESK.
(TAPPING ON A PAGE) This is it. He’s coming here. Tonight!
How can you be sure, Dr Smith?
Agent Tulip. Henrick Van Nyman. He’s known to British intelligence.
I see. (CHECKING PAPERS) And these messages place Spark and Tulip... together.
They were about to take a holiday. As of... (CHECKS PAPERS) yesterday. They arrive this evening.
You think you might send someone to intercept them?
Oh, I think we can do better than that. (PUSHING PAPERS ACROSS DESK) Here. Check the map reference.
Cambridgeshire. I know it.
Fetch Mrs Clarke would you, Sylvia.
Sir?
I can’t have you drive us off to Cambridgeshire without her say-so, can I?
Me? Drive you, sir?
Your Leading Wren is quite formidable. I’d much rather have her on my side. Chop-chop, Miss Wimpole. See if you can rally a few strapping lads as well.
Beg pardon, sir?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 21

We just need them to carry my ‘police box’ downstairs. You and I and Wren Clarke will take it along. It contains specialist equipment. (SOTTO) And if there’s the slightest chance of getting any of it working again...
I wondered what it is you keep in there.
Highly advanced radio receivers, transmitters, decoders. That kind of thing.
(EXITING) I’1ll round up some boys.
(TO SELF) Oh yes, my TARDIS is full of technological wonders. But at present, they’re all completely and utterly useless.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 14: INT. INTERROGATION ROOM, BLETCHLEY
TALKING ON THE TELEPHONE.
I think it’s quite clear sir. He’s offered every excuse to avoid an interview. He could hardly be more blatant.
BURBLE ON PHONE.
Dr John Smith. No credentials. His identity evaporates as soon as one examines it too closely.
BURBLE ON PHONE.
No, I do not need to refer it to the Prime Minister’s office. I am quite capable of reaching my own conclusion. And that conclusion is the man’s a spy.
BURBLE ON PHONE.

I don’t know how he hoodwinked the authorities to get in here. Swanning around like he owns the place by all accounts. Talked Travis into giving him a room at the Main House. One of Tiltman’s old offices. Upstairs. Not only that, but he’s seconded one of the huts. Redesignated it Twelve-A.
I shall be recommending a formal review of procedures here. As for how to deal with this Dr Smith. The usual form for a spy.
Questioned and shot. If he resists, the questions may have to
be foregone.
BURBLE ON PHONE.
Of course I'll do it discreetly. Minimal presence. No point
startling the geese. Expect to hear from me in an hour. Then I’m off to the country. I’ve that other matter to attend to.
PHONE RECEIVER ON CRADLE. GETS UP, LOADS REVOLVER.
(CALLING) Captain Walters! With me.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 15: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
BUILDING RADIO RECEIVER DEVICE. CONSTANCE KNOCKS AND ENTERS.
You sent for me, Doctor?
Mrs Clarke. I need a vehicle.
So I’ve been told. If you fill out the usual requisition forms...
(INTERRUPTING) There’s no time for that!
We must follow procedure.
Procedure be blowed! I have made a breakthrough and speed is of the essence.
Sir, I-
I have located agents with knowledge that may be key to the security of the world.
The world? You mean the country, surely?
I know what I mean. Sometimes, we need to bypass official procedures. If there’s an urgency. If we can save lives. SO please, Mrs Clarke — the truck?
GOES TO DOOR AND OPENS IT.
(STOPPING) One thing, sir. Is Agent Spark involved?

Agent Spark is more vital than any of you realise. And if we’re to have any hope of catching up with him, we need to leave now. I’ll bring the maps and this... device when I’ve finished building it. I’ll meet you at the gate in five minutes.
Yes sir! (EXITS, CLOSING DOOR)
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 16: EXT. OUTSIDE BLETCHLEY MANSION
HARRIS AND TWO SOLDIERS WALKING UP TO MANSION.
This shouldn’t be too difficult. He’s got his feet squarely under the table. Complacent. Unwary. (STOPPING) Are you ready to catch a spy, Captain?
Yes, sir!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 17: EXT. GARAGES, BLETCHLEY
PULLS OUT OF GARAGE.
(APPROACHING, CALLING) Wren Wimpole! You have the police box?
STOPS, ENGINE IDLING.
(CALLING FROM CAB) Loaded up and ready to go. Where’s Dr Smith?
OPENS PASSENGER DOOR.
(CLIMBING IN) He’s joining us at the gate. (CLOSING DOOR) Shall we?
PULLS AWAY.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 26
SCENE 18: INT. ENTRANCE HALL, BLETCHLEY MANSION
HARRIS AND SOLDIERS ENTER FOYER.
You know which is his office?
Up the stairs, sir!
LEADS SOLDIERS UP THE STAIRS ONTO LANDING.
Men like him avoid the front. They haven’t seen what I’ve seen,
Captain.
This is the one, sir.
THEY ALL STOP. HARRIS HAMMERS ON DOOR.
(CALLING) Open up, Dr Smith. The game’s up.
(MUFFLED) One moment please!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 19: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY (CONTINUOUS)
HAMMERING ON DOOR.
(TO HIMSELF) Ah. The persistent Major Harris. I was hoping to be away before any awkward questions arose.
(OUTSIDE) Let me in, Smith!
(CALLING) Just a moment. I’m on a particularly tricky section of the crossword!
TRIES HANDLE. IT’S LOCKED.
(OUTSIDE) Unlock this door!
Oh, is it locked? Sorry! I’ve mislaid my key... (TO SELF) Think, Doctor, think!
(OUTSIDE) Open up! This is your last chance.
BANGS ON DOOR.
It’s not even as if I can retreat to the TARDIS now it’s outside on that truck.
OPENS WINDOW. TRUCK IDLING, OFF.
Speaking of which... Ah.
(OUTSIDE) I’m coming in. Break it down boys.
HARRIS AND MEN STARTS BATTERING THE DOOR — CONTINUES THROUGH.
PUSHES WINDOW FULLY OPEN AND STARTS CLIMBING OUT.
(CALLING) I believe I have the solution. Fourteen letters. Starts with a D. ‘Involuntary exit through the window’.
INSIDE, THE DOOR STARTS TO GIVE WAY UNDER REPEATED BATTERING.
CLAMBERS ALONG GUTTERING.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 28
(CLIMBING) Sometimes, I make the most undignified exits...
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 20: INT. TRUCK AT BLETCHLEY PARK GATE
IDLING.
Where is Dr Smith? He was the one who wanted to leave ina hurry...
BEEPS HORN.
He still does ma’am. Look! In the mirror!
RUNNING UP.
Well, I’ve never seen a boffin with such a turn of speed.
CLAMBERS INTO BACK OF TRUCK.
(BREATHLESS) What are you waiting for? Wren Wimpole, drive!
PULLS AWAY.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 21: EXT. OUTSIDE BLETCHLEY MANSION
HARRIS AND SOLDIERS RUN OUT FROM MANSION
He got away?
Yes sir. Sorry sir.
He simply drove off through the back gate while we were knocking at his door?
It looks that way, sir. Wren Clarke was with him. She cleared it with the sentry.
Under duress, no doubt. The scoundrel. Well, does anyone know where he’s going?
Sorry sir, we think the only people who have any idea... well, he’s taken them with him!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 22: INT. LORRY
LORRY, BUMPY DRIVING B/G
We’re miles from anywhere. Where are we going?
Eyes on the road, Miss Wimpole. Constance? Anything from that device of mine?
Nothing yet. What’s it supposed to do?
You’1l know when it does it.
It’ll be dark soon. We shouldn’t be out on the road during Blackout.
I’m afraid the agents of the German Abwehr don’t keep office hours. Needs must. Mrs Clarke, hand me that torch. I need to check where we are on the map...
I already did, Doctor. We’ll be at that reference very soon.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 32
SCENE 23: EXT. FACTORY FENCE
RATTLING OF FENCE AS FLINT SETS EXPLOSIVE CHARGES.
(JUST OFF, LOW) Is this the best place to put them?
Leave it to me, Dutch. I’m the expert at explosives. You’re the expert at.. what is it? Making cheese?
I’ll be glad when we are finished working together Mr Flint. Your humour is sometimes abrasive.
When we’re done here, I’ve got to go see a man about a dog. You clear the camp.
You want to see a dog?
It’s an expression. Half an hour.
Half an hour where though?
It’s a big dog. If I didn’t know better, I’d think you’d been sent along to nursemaid me. You wouldn’t be doing that would you? Spying on a spy?
Get on with your job, English. Once the factory blows up, I will report back and everyone will be happy. You, me, Dr Schwartzmann and Herr Hitler.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 33
SCENE 24: EXT. FIELD
ONGOING. ARMY LORRY PULLS UP AND THE DOCTOR, CONSTANCE AND
JUMP DOWN INTO MUD. DOCTOR'S RADIO RECEIVER WHISTLES AND CLICKS.
Does that sound mean we’re tracking something?
Indeed it does. This way I think.
THEY START WALKING THROUGH MUD.
According to the maps, the factory buildings are over in that direction. I think I can make them out. (WALKING OFF) But what’s this...
(WITH EFFORT IN MUD) Sorry about this, ladies. I hope you’re wearing sturdy boots.
(WITH EFFORT, GETTING STUCK IN MUD) A Wren is always prepared, sir.
(A LITTLE FURTHER OFF) Shine the light over here, Wren Wimpole.
THEY STOP, POKING A PILE OF STICKS AND EMBERS.
It looks like the remains of a fire.
Well-spotted. A camp. A very makeshift camp. We’re close.
Lucky for us the rain’s been bucketing down quite some time.
You’ve an unusual opinion on what constitutes good fortune, Mrs Clarke.
I’m soaked to the skin already!
Look. Down there. What else do you see?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 34
Footprints!
Very good. Sylvia? See if you can turn up anything here in the camp. But be careful.
Ma’am?

(GETTING UP) What about the bomb?
(WALKING OVER TO BOX) Let me check something.
Doctor. Is it wise to pick up boxes of dynamite and shake them? They may still be- (GASPS)
RATTLES EMPTY BOXES TOGETHER
No. A slight correction to your assumption. These are not boxes of dynamite. They are dynamite boxes — which are empty.
But that means... All of this... Why would anyone go to the trouble of setting an alarm clock on a factory fence?
Why indeed?

SCENE 29: INT. HANGAR
FOOTSTEPS AND SCRAPE AS FLINT PULLS UP A CHAIR.
WHISTLES ‘RULE BRITANNIA’
OUTSIDE. HARRIS ENTERS AND HANGAR DOOR CLANGS CLOSED.
Ah, Mr Flint. You’ve not been waiting long, I hope. I apologise for the slight delay — I’d some other business to take care of.
No trouble to me, Major Harris. Good to be on my own for a bit. Rid of my babysitter.
You weren’t expecting an accomplice on your mission?
No. The Dutchman was a complication. I made sure he saw me set the fuses, the timer. I just didn’t let on that they wasn’t wired into anything.
Well done. My men will be here soon. We’1ll tidy things up. Set off a small detonation. Then tomorrow, we’1ll run the story. Let the Germans believe our engine production has been compromised.
Just like Mr Hitler wanted.
And while they believe that, they’1ll be happy to take you back again.
Happy that I’ve done my bit for the Fuhrer’s cause.
Indeed. That way, German Intelligence remain in blissful ignorance about their precious Agent Spark.
That’s right. Agent Spark don’t even work for them. (CHUCKLES) There’s no such fella. Agent Criss-Cross reporting for duty, Sirs

DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE HURRY TO SYLVIA.
There she is!
Next to this poor fellow. A gun. But civilian clothes. That Says spy to me. Agent Spark?
Or Agent Tulip. (HE CHECKS DUTCH’S BODY)
(CHECKING SYLVIA) Wren Wimpole? Sylvia?

I am already doing it Doctor! She’s breathing. Her pulse is regular.
MOANS

THE DOCTOR’S RADIO RECEIVER WHISTLES AND CLICKS.
Your machine. It’s making a noise.

Signals?
Electromagnetic signals. He was killed by radio waves.

SCENE 31: INT. HANGAR
PACES THOUGHOUT.
We'll get you to Camp Oh-Two-Oh for proper debriefing. Then arrange transportation back to Europe.
Back to my home from home. I’1l say this for them Nazis, they’ve got a better wine cellar than your shower.
We'll let van Nyman get away. He’1ll corroborate your mission’s success.
Ah. Might be a problem with that. The Dutchman’s dead.
What? You killed him?
Whoah whoah whoah. Not me sir. There was some dolly-bird spark out beside him too. Must’ve been your lot. Trying to get their hands on my goodies.
My lot?
Wrens. Saw another one sniffing around the fence with some bloke. I thought they were all with you.
No. My men will pick them up, whoever they are. They’1l be reporting in any moment. (BEAT) I wonder...

(STOPPING) I like to keep moving. It helps the circulation. Oxygen to the brain. You worry me, Flint. You take too many risks.
That’s what the copper said who took me in after the Bermondsey bank job.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 47
Well that’s probably why you kept getting caught.

You know what he said? The last beak that sent me down in England? (IMITATING JUDGE) ‘You’re a petty criminal Mr Flint. From a line of petty criminals. I expect to be sentencing you, and the rest of your family for the rest of my career.’ If he could see me now, eh?
So you moved to Paris.
And then the gendarmes had it in for me too.
If you insist on raiding their jewellery stores... Lucky for us, that your allegiances are so fluid.
They believe me. You believe me. Only I know the truth. Any word on my cousins? You keeping them out of trouble?
For the most part. You know that was the deal.
That little toe-rag Billy will be the death of his ma.
RAPPING AT HANGAR DOOR.
Ah. My men.
GOES TO OPEN HANGAR DOOR
Soldier boys. They make me nervous most of all. Fellas willing to give up control of their lives to someone with more stripes on their arm? Makes no sort of sense to me.
Captain?
Sir! There’s someone at the factory.
Told you. Lucky I went and fetched this first. (HEFTS HIS
ONTO HIS LAP)
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 48
Watch them. (MUSING) They may be civilians. (DECIDES) No... I’11 need to question them. Stay under cover. Ready for a pinch. Inform me when you’re in position.
Yes sir! (MARCHES OFF OUTSIDE)
What is it you’ve got in that knapsack, Flint?
(OPENING KNAPSACK) A little souvenir. Something the Germans were very interested in.
DORMANT STATIC HUM OF COMMUNICATION POD.
What is it? It looks like one of those Faberge eggs. More stolen treasures destined for the Fuhrer? He won’t be pleased you’ve got your grubby hands on it.
Nah. This came from somewhere else. They keep finding ‘em floating off the Brittany coast. Think it might be some kind of radio technology. I nicked it off my German C.O.
You did what? See what I mean Flint? Risks! I hope they don’t know it’s gone missing.

Sir!

GO TO HELP CARRY EQUIPMENT ALONG JETTY.

(HANDLING POD) Not quite like Dutch. It has offensive capabilities, then?
Dunno. I’ve not seen it do that before.
Some new secret weapon? A new Enigma machine?
That’s what I reckon. Listen close. And you can hear it talking.

RUNS UP FROM OUTSIDE

I’m sure you can. (TO SOLDIER) Captain, you’re ready to move in?

might be able to identify whatever caused her collapse.
MOANS
Your... TARDIS? What kind of name is that for a.. a.. (CAN’T FIND THE WORDS) Well, it’s not even a hut!
Trust me. Please, Mrs Clarke. We’ve come this far?
TARDIS.
Yes. And look where it’s got young Sylvia.
(OFF) Halt! You are surrounded!
BREAK COVER FROM TREES AROUND THEM.
Oh no.
(OFF) Hold your fire, men. You’1ll hit the women. (WALKING FORWARD) Release your hostages, Smith, and we can talk.
Hostages?

It’s a radio receiver. Nothing more deadly than that.
So you can stay in touch with your German spymasters?

SETTING: ROTORS.
SYLVIA: (EXCHANGING PAPERS WITH CONSTANCE) That’s everything over the Bay of Biscay, ma’am.
CONSTANCE: Thanks you. (EXCHANGING PAPERS) Now, onto the Luftwaffe. Here are the cribs for Red and for Snowdrop. (TO WREN) Wren Page, take the Biscay wheel and plugboard settings over to the Type-X girls.
WREN: Yes ma’am!
DOOR: OPENS, WREN DEPARTS, DOCTOR ENTERS WITH CRACKLING, HISSING WAVEFORM.
DOCTOR: Marvellous work, ladies. We’ve an excellent hit rate the last few hours. What have we got?
CONSTANCE: U-boat co-ordinates. Gun positions. Aircraft movements. The translators in Twelve-A seem to have built up a head of steam.
DOCTOR: That’1ll be the TARDIS lending a hand.
CONSTANCE: We've still got the Tunny messages to run. The ones from Berlin.
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 97
DOCTOR: Yes.. a trickier prospect. I’ll take a look at those myself. But I’m hoping this decoded traffic will be enough to carve a path. Waveform, can you make sense of them?
WAVEFORM: (FX) The codes. They are understood. We see. We see a way between the waves.
SYLVIA: (CALLING) All set. We’re on another run!
BOMBE: MACHINE RESTARTS. ROTORS CLATTERING RHYTHMICALLY. THE
WAVEFORM: HISSING FADES THROUGH FOLLOWING AS IT SLIPS AWAY.
DOCTOR: Separating sense from the codes. The medium and the message. We can’t unscramble everything. But if the Waveform has a crib, a working hypothesis of where to begin, then our alien intelligence can complete its own analysis. Just like these machines. ‘Thinking’ machines. Your Mr Turing truly is a genius.
CONSTANCE: I was on duty the night they made the breakthrough. Spring of ‘41. I'd not been here long. And of course, no-one said exactly what they’d done. But we knew. Suddenly, there were so many more decrypts for translation. We knew, but we never spoke a word.
DOCTOR: A hundred and fifty nine million, million, million combinations. And that was the easy nut to crack.
CONSTANCE: Then came Shark. Another rotor wheel on the naval Enigma.
DOCTOR: Multiplying the possibilities. But the same principles cracked it. These magnificent bombe machines. Bletchley almost puts Logopolis to shame. Human ingenuity never ceases to amaze me.
BOMBE: MACHINE WHIRS. WAVEFORM SOUND HAS STOPPED.
CONSTANCE: Where did it go?
DOCTOR: What?
CONSTANCE: The Waveform. It was here with us. Then it... faded away.
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 98
DOCTOR: As quickly as we’ve been working, it may not have been enough. It could have been subsumed by the sheer volume of radio traffic in the atmosphere. (CALLING) Hello? Waveform? Are you receiving?
CRACKLING: CHUADRI FORMS.
DOCTOR: Ah. It’s coming through...
BOMBE: MACHINERY HALTS. BUZZER SOUNDS.
SYLVIA: (JUST OFF) We have a stop!
CHUADRI: SOLIDIFIES.
CONSTANCE: That’s not the Waveform. It’s one of those Chuadri!
SYLVIA: (APPROACHING) One of... what, ma’am? (GASPS) There are more behind the bombes.
WRENS: MOVE AWAY IN ALARM.
DOCTOR: Why is it summoning them? I’m freeing the Waveform. I thought understanding was all it needed.
CHUADRI: (FX) Message received. Awaiting transmission.
DOCTOR: Oh no. Carry on, Sylvia! (HEADS TO DOOR) Constance, with me!
CONSTANCE: I’m not leaving my Wrens while these creatures are threatening them.
DOCTOR: (OPENING DOOR) They’re not. They’re standing guard. They won’t harm your ladies. Not while they’re doing its work. (GOES OUTSIDE) Come on!
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 99
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 57: EXT. PATHS BETWEEN HUTS, BLETCHLEY (CONTINUOUS)
MULTIPLE: CHUADRI MATERIALISING, OFF. CONSTANCE EXITS HUT.
CONSTANCE: (CATCHING UP) Where do you think the Waveform is?
DOCTOR: (WALKING) Everywhere!
CONSTANCE: How do we communicate with it? Find out what it’s doing?
DOCTOR: Right now, I’ve no idea. But we can start with those pods, back in my office.
CONSTANCE: Actually. We should stop off somewhere first. (TAKING THE LEAD) Don’t worry, Doctor, it’s on the way!
CONSTANCE: THEY HURRY ON.
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 100
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 58: EXT. LAKESIDE, BLETCHLEY
DOCTOR WHO: RUSTLING IN BUSHES.
EFFY: We shouldn’t be out here, Cyril. The Major said everyone should stay indoors.
CYRIL: But this is my best chance to get you alone, Effy darling.
EFFY: Oh Cyril!
EFFY: THEY SMOOCH. CHUADRI START FORMING.
EFFY: Cyril. Wait. Someone’s here. Oh. What are they?
CYRIL: Remarkable. Silver ghosts. From thin air.
EFFY: Is it.. them? Are we invaded?
CHUADRI: (FX, BECOMING MORE DISTINCT THROUGH FOLLOWING) One. One. Nine. Four. Zero. Zero. Nine.
CYRIL: No. It’s like a statue. Is it.. speaking? (APPROACHES THROUGH BUSHES) I wonder. If I... (ZAPPED BY CHUADRI) Aaagh!
CHUADRI: (FX) These minds. Full of thoughts. Numbers. Waves.
EFFY: Cyril! No! (TURNS TO RUN)
ANOTHER: CHUADRI WALKS FORWARD AND ZAPS HER.
EFFY: Aaaagh!
CHUADRI: (FX) Waves absorbed.
WAVEFORM: (FX, AS IF VIA RADIO TRANSMISSION) We gain understanding. We are everywhere. Transmit.
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 101
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 59: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
DOCTOR WHO: DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE RUN UPSTAIRS AND INTO OFFICE.
DOCTOR: Where’s Harris? Where’s Flint?
SCHWARTZMANN: The Major seems content to leave me tied to this chair with a guard on the door. Mr Flint... vanished with my golden eggs.
DOCTOR: The Waveform’s played me for a fool. It’s already cracked all the codes it needs.
CONSTANCE: Doctor?
DOCTOR: It wanted freeing from its underwater prison. And like an idiot, I did exactly what it wanted.
WAVEFORM: HISSES AND CRACKLES INTO EXISTENCE.
WAVEFORM: (FX) We will conquer all radio frequencies. They envelop this planet. We will ride them and disseminate our Chuadri soldiers.
DOCTOR: Why? This world is irrelevant to you. The Earth has nothing to do with your war.
WAVEFORM: (FX) This ‘Earth’ is a resource in that conflict. First, every electrical impulse can be absorbed.
LIGHTNING: ZAPS SOLDIER OUTSIDE DOOR.
CONSTANCE: The guard!
WAVEFORM: (FX) We test human signals. The bodies do not conduct.
CONSTANCE: Doctor, you said... every thought. Every nerve signal. They contain electrical energy.
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 102
DOCTOR: But it’s tiny. The amount of power the Waveform would gain from a human being is infinitesimally small.
WAVEFORM: (FX) Billions exist on this world. Moving. Thinking. Fighting. If they cannot be harnessed, we cleanse this rock of life. Then absorb power from the electromagnetic fields that cross it.
PANICKING: CRIES OF ALARM OUTSIDE. CONSTANCE RUSHES TO WINDOW.
CONSTANCE: What’s happening out there?
WAVEFORM: (FX) We must expand our range.
CHUADRI: MANIFESTING OUTSIDE. GUNSHOTS. CRIES.
CONSTANCE: (LOOKING OUT OF WINDOW) There are more Chuadri appearing in the grounds, Doctor.
GUNFIRE: OUTSIDE.
DOCTOR: It’s no good fighting. We need to use our heads. (GOING TO
UNTIE: SCHWARTZMANN) Here, Schwartzmann, let’s get you untied.
SCHWARTZMANN: (BEING RELEASED) Thank you. I suppose it is too much to ask for the return of my weapon to defend myself? (FREED, HE STANDS)
DOCTOR: Yes. In any case, it won’t do much good.
CONSTANCE: I’ll find Major Harris. Tell him to pull the men back inside.
CONSTANCE: OPENS DOOR. FLINT BLOCKS HER WAY.
FLINT: (ENTERING) Whoah! Hold up, Mrs. Where you hurrying off to? Did I miss the start of the party?
DOCTOR: (PREOCCUPIED) How? The Waveform could only make headway if it knew ciphers from both sides. If it’s been able to decode a proportion of the signals from the start. How did it gain that knowledge?
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 103
SCHWARTZMANN: Ha! You are betrayed, I think. It is obvious, is it not?
CONSTANCE: Yes. Of course. Of course it is. (BEAT) What did they promise you? Mr Flint.
FLINT: (DRAWS GUN) Nothing much. Just mastery of the whole world. Sort of puts Dr Schwartzmann’s and Major Harris’s payments in the shade.
DOCTOR: Agent Criss-Cross.
FLINT: Hande hoch — Doctor, Mrs Clarke!
WAVEFORM: (FX) Our signals attuned to this human’s mind. We ratified our agreement beneath the sea.
FLINT: You might say, we’re on the same wavelength.
DOCTOR: You'd really do this? Betray your whole species? Your whole planet?
FLINT: If I get to run it. Yeah. Why not? First job on the list, though... is to get rid of you, Dr Smith.
PISTOL: COCKED.
PISTOL: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 104

elements.text: PART FOUR
Agent Criss-Cross.
(FX) Our signals attuned to this human’s mind. We ratified our agreement beneath the sea.
You might say, we’re on the same wavelength.
You’d really do this? Betray your whole species? Your whole planet?
If I get to run it. Yeah. Why not? First job on the list, though... is to get rid of you, Dr Smith.
COCKED.
SCENE 60: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY (CONTINUOUS)
I think not, Mr Flint.
BURST OF RADIO NOISE.
(FX, VERY DISTORTED, SIGNAL BREAKING UP) We are manifesting. Do not block the transmission!
Aaagh!! (COLLAPSES AND DROPS GUN)
Good work, Constance!
What did you do?
Signal jammer. I thought those bits and bobs in the old radio hut would be useful.
Very resourceful, your British sparrows.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 105
Wrens, Dr Schwartzmann. The word is Wrens.
Let’s congratulate Constance later. The effect won’t last. Flint and the Waveform are linked, they’1ll recover together. Come on both of you. Run!
DOCTOR, CONSTANCE AND SCHWARTZMANN FLEE FROM OFFICE.
(FX, DISTORTED) No signal! No.. signal!
(RECOVERING) S’all right... they won’t get far.
(FX, RECOVERING) We receive... Transmit! Transmit!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 106
SCENE 61: EXT. BLETCHLEY PARK, OUTSIDE MANSION
CHUADRI WHINE LIKE DETUNED RADIOS IN B/G THROUGHOUT. GUNSHOTS AND METALLIC RICOHETS AS BULLETS HIT THEM.
This is no longer a drill. They’ve halted. Keep firing till the blighters fall over!
SHOTS.
(CALLING) Captain Walters! Keep the civilians inside, away from windows! We’ll engage hand-to-hand if we must.
DOCTOR, CONSTANCE AND SCHWARTZMANN RUN FROM MANSION.
(OFF, RUNNING TOWARDS THEM) Hold your fire!
(CALLING) Cease fire! Doctor, is that you?
STOPS. SOLDIERS RUN FOR COVER.
(RUNNING UP) Please, Major. Your men must stop shooting at
them. We’ve seen what they do.
(RUNNING UP) It is a far from pleasant way to die.
Wren Clarke. Why is my prisoner running around Bletchley?
The alternative was to let the Waveform disintegrate him!
I am grateful.
Still. He’s a Nazi spy!
Worry about that later. Order your men to cover. We need to get back to the huts. How many hostiles are there?
HURRY ALONG PATHWAY THROUGH FOLLOWING.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 107
Couple of dozen appeared out in the open. Started advancing on the House, but suddenly stopped. Like silver statues.
Constance afforded us a small respite. But it won’t be long before the Chuadri recover and then they will retaliate.
What do we do next, Doctor?
We need Sylvia from the bombe room. You’ve given me an idea, Constance.
What about these silver ghosts? What did you call them? These ‘Chuadri’ ?
By my understanding, so long as there are unbroken codes in the ether around us, the Waveform’s movement is restricted.
That’s the trouble. Flint’s given it enough of the ciphers from both sides to gain a foothold.
Flint?
Your Agent Criss-Cross switched sides. Again.
The creature spoke of expanding its range.

Its range increases exponentially so long as it keeps deciphering whatever’s being carried in the surrounding radio waves. It may only control a half-mile radius now, but ina very few hours, it could be hundreds or even thousands of miles.
Scattered with Chuadri warriors. Ready to zap the human race to kingdom come. (HAPPY GASP OF REALISATION) That’s it, Doctor! It won’t have hours.
Mrs Clarke?
THEY ALL STOP.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 108
What a stroke of luck! It doesn’t even have minutes. Look at the time! (CHECKS WATCH) Listen! (BEAT) Three. Two. One.
RING IN ALL THE HUTS, OFF.
Oh, that’s marvellous!
Midnight! The Germans have changed the codes.
As they do every day. What does it mean?
It means, Major, that for a precious few minutes, The Waveform is back at square one. We have some breathing space. Where’s that radio hut, Constance?
There. Across the lawn.

It won’t take long for Flint to bring his ally up to speed. He’s got codebooks stolen from your side, Schwartzmann, and yours Major. I’d guess we have thirty minutes at most! (RUSHES OFF, CALLING) See you in Hut Twelve-A!
START CRACKLING AND FADING AWAY.
The quicksilver men. They’re evaporating!

Good Lord. (CALLING) Walters! Take up positions inside. Windows and doors. Cover every entrance. (HANDING GUN TO CONSTANCE) Wren Clarke. Take my pistol. Keep our visitor under guard. I’1l give my men their orders, then join you presently. (HURRIES
Sir! Onward, Dr Schwartzmann, if you please. (MARCHES HIM ON)
What are we doing?
You heard the Doctor. Your German military intelligence has just granted us half an hour to save the world.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 109
SCENE 62: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
STATIC OF COMMUNICATION PODS B/G.
(FX, HISSING CONTINUOUS RADIO SIGNAL UNDER FOLLOWING — GROUPS OF THREE LETTERS AT RANDOM)
K—-A—E.C—-X-—-—V. H-—-T—P.L—Q-—C. etc
(FX) Hurry, Flint, hurry.
FLICKS THROUGH CODEBOOKS, MOVING PODS ACROSS THROUGH FOLLOWING.
These eggs of yours are fiddly little blighters. Do I have to roll them over every page in every book?
(FX) All the codes. We must know all the codes.
I’m going as quick as I can.
(FX) You have read all these pages yourself?
Glanced at them. Flicked through, like.
(FX) Then the impression will be in your mind...
The Germans at the chateau said I’d a good memory, but I’m not a bleedin’ elephant! It’s not photographic!
(FX) It does not need to be. The records are somewhere in your brain. The signals can be located.
STATIC CRACKLES AROUND FLINT.
Agh! Hold on one flamin’ minute!
(FX) You are prepared to make sacrifices to gain your reward?
I’m not gonna sacrifice my noggin!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 110
(FX) It will not come to that. Relax, Flint. The signals will be clearer.
CRACKLING INCREASES. FLINT DROPS THE EGGS.
Aaagh!
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 111
SCENE 63: INT. HUT TWELVE-A, BLETCHLEY
KNOCK AT DOOR. SYLVIA ENTERS.
You sent for me, ma’am?
Actually, I did. I need a cryptological genius. Since Alan is engaged with Delilah at Hanslope Park-
Delilah? I don’t think [Mr-]
Delilah is an enciphering machine.
Ah.
Since he’s so crucial to this period of history, I’d rather not disturb him. You will more than suffice as a substitute, Sylvia.
Me, sir? Are you sure, sir? Can’t you do it?

I shall be otherwise occupied. Now listen. I need you to create a cipher. One the Waveform would have no hope of cracking. The message, I will provide. Once you’ve encoded it — I’1l need you, Wren Clarke, to transmit it.
Should I fetch a Type-X machine sir?
No. We must keep this code ‘off-line’. You need to create it with pen and paper. And your brain. Here. I’1l write down what I want you to say. (GRABS PEN AND WRITES) Just a couple of lines.
Herr Doctor. Frau Clarke. If I might interject?
Yes?
Ciphers are my business. I will help.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 112
SCENE 64: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
HISSING OF WAVEFORM B/G.
(MOANS, RECOVERING) Got what you needed?
(FX) We process the decryptions. Your brain is unharmed.
Urgh. Don’t feel like it. (RUBS HEAD) We won’t be doing that again in a hurry. Will we?
(FX) These codes remain constant for one day?
That’s right. They’1ll change again at midnight.
(FX) We will not need that long. Soon our Chuadri manifest once more.
You reckon you can finish this today?
(FX) We detect which wavelengths are most vital. We consume the Signals. Signals we use to build our army. We will spread across this sphere as frequencies fall under our control.
You reckon you’1ll have a big enough army to take down the Germans? The Brits? The Russians and the Yanks?
(FX) The Chuadri will be without number once every field of the spectrum is ours.
Then I get to run things, right?
(FX) You will be the modulator of the harvest of planet Earth.
‘Modulator’? Sounds a bit poncey. Can’t I just be King? Or Emperor, maybe?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 113
(FX) We warn you, Emperor Flint, most humans will not survive. Few will remain for you to rule.
(CHUCKLES) ‘Emperor Flint’. Like it. That’s all right, me old mucker. Never been big on making friends.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 114
SCENE 65: INT. HUT TWELVE-A, BLETCHLEY
SCRIBBLING ON PAPERS. HARRIS KNOCKS, ENTERS AND
DOOR.
All quiet. No sign of those silver blighters. Yet.
Everyone’s indoors?
Yes. I’ve put a temporary stop on traffic in or out. There’s already a half-dozen despatch riders at the gate.
We need to deal with this quickly. I can’t let it affect history. Your war goes on, but we’ve got to win this one first...
My men report Flint’s holed up in your office. We could storm it-
No. He’s got the Waveform on his side.
At close range, it takes human beings apart.
We are defeating it with something more than brute force.
What about your police box? Your... ship?
Still mired in the Waveform’s signal. I have all I need right here. The fewer people who know what we’re doing the better.
So now we wait. (BEAT) You couldn’t brew up some tea, Miss Wimpole?
Pardon, Major?
Yes, sir.
No — as you were, Sylvia. Major, do you have a mathematical degree?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 115
Well, I, er...
Do you have a first from Oxford in Modern Languages?
I speak French, and bit of German-
It’s not just words. It’s a mindset. Transferring meaning from one set of symbols to another. Can you do that?
No.
Well those who can need tea. Brew it yourself. Sir.
Actually, Major, you can accompany me. There’s a task I have in mind.
I was thinking, Doctor. Couldn’t you send an order? If it’s using radio waves for power, then we could stop them. Order radio silence. Just a short while. Dr Schwartzmann, you could ask too.
(SCORNFULLY) You think German High Command would listen?
No. The worst thing we could do now is disrupt radio traffic. History must take its course. Any interference would be catastrophic. (SIGH) At least the whole thing will be over this time next year.
The whole... sorry, what?
Erm. Forget I said that. Even a temporary halt to transmissions would endanger the war’s outcome.
You just said, the end of the war was coming. Next year?
We'll live to see next year. That’s what I meant. — Major. Are you ready?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 116
Yes, Doctor.
Bring that big metal doorstop would you? (EXITING) I’1l need to get past any newly-formed Chuadri at the Mansion.
(PICKING UP LARGE MAGNET) With a doorstop?
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 117
SCENE 66: EXT. OUTSIDE BLETCHLEY MANSION
HARRIS AND DOCTOR APPROACH MANSION CAUTIOUSLY, TAKING COVER IN
AS PLANES PASS OVERHEAD. USE HUSHED TONES.
There they go. Goodness knows where Jerry’s set his sights tonight.
There are messages out there that could tell you. We need to get Bletchley back to work.
I could try what the girl suggested, Doctor. Order radio blackout.
No, you can’t. Ultra is vital. Especially now.
CHUADRI FORM IN GROUNDS.
The foot-soldiers are returning. It must be making progress with the codes.
If we can’t beat this thing. If it starts to gain the upper hand... There are alternatives. A bombing run. On our own soil. There'd be ways of making it look [like-]
No! It can’t come to that. You’ve no idea how important this place is.
We may not have a choice.
Then we’d better get on with it. Get rid of any extra- terrestrial interference in good time for Overlord.
Good grief. How do you-
(INTERRUPTING) The same reason I know about the aerial mast being installed at Hut Eighteen. I told you before: friends in high places. One friend in particular.
I did wonder.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 118
You and your men have your assignment. Dismantle that equipment and run a loop right around the perimeter. Wrens Clarke and Wimpole will do the rest with the message I gave them to encode.
I still don’t understand your part, Doctor. Strolling into the lion’s den? Flint and that creature won’t leave your office. They won’t let you near your TARDIS. What do you hope to achieve?
GETS UP, WALKING TOWARDS MANSION.
I’m simply doing what I came here to do in the first place, Major. I’m going fishing.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 119
SCENE 67: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE, BLETCHLEY
WAVEFORM B/G
(FX) Transmitting. Radius expanding. Two miles. The codes are elaborate but we receive them.
MATERIALISE OUTSIDE.
Good-oh. Our silver army’s back in business. The rest of the world won’t know what hit it.
(FX) Something slows us. Obstructs our view. Listen.
TELEPRINTER SIGNALS EMERGE FROM STATIC.
(FX) More complex signals. Help us decipher them.
I don’t know what that is. Sounds different from my box of tricks.
(AT DOORWAY) That’s the Lorenz. German High Command’s coded teleprinter signal.
You what?
(FX) Doctor...

(STROLLING INTO ROOM) British Intelligence has never seen one, but they built the Tunny to replicate its operation. Twelve rotors. More letters. Billions of combinations. It’1ll take you a little longer to decrypt. That’s why Bletchley built Colossus.
Oi. What are you doing here? How’d you get past our guards?
My magnetic personality. Well. A large enough magnet to stun them. But look. (PLACES MAGNET ON TABLE) I’m giving it up. I come in peace.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 120
(FX) We will disperse your signals.
STATIC.
Wait! I came to talk.
The Waveform’s done with you, Doctor. It’s my turn now.
On the contrary, Mr Flint. I’m here to see you. To beg an audience with the ruler of the world in waiting.
Nah. You just want your police box.
(DISMISSIVE) Oh, no. My TARDIS is as good as useless. I am here to appeal to you as a fellow human being. Well, near enough.
What’s your game? Are you hidin’ something?
(FX) The Doctor conceals no devices.
We could save the people, Flint. Your people. Wouldn’t you rather rule as a hero than a tyrant?
I dunno. Caviar tastes the same either way. How can I save ‘em?

The Waveform can absorb what it needs from the Earth. Persuade it to spare the people. There are many potential energy sources. There are machines here that can calculate- (BREAKS OFF) No. I’ve said too much.
Don’t matter. Sounds like too much trouble to me. I’1ll stick with the original plan.
You really have no moral scruples at all, have you Mr Flint?
Got me where I am today.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 121

And where’s that? Do you think this war’s made you a hero? Just because you can play one side off against the other? Or are you simply a self-serving sociopath, who’s found a comfortable niche while all around him burns?
Of the two of us Doc, I’m the one who’s gonna see the sun rise tomorrow. That puts me ahead.
With the Waveform running the show, I wouldn’t count on it.
(FX) The Doctor conceals meaning. Calculating machines?
Here. Hang about. It’s got a point. What’s that Colossus you were on about?
(FEIGNING IGNORANCE) Did I mention a ‘Colossus’?
Tell us.
(FX) We sense... electrical fields. This machine is close. These Signals can be decoded.
No, really. I don’t think it’1l be any good to you. You seem to be doing perfectly well without- (GRABBED BY FLINT)
(GRABBING DOCTOR) Show us.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 122
SCENE 68: INT. HUT TWELVE-A, BLETCHLEY
FINISHES SCRIBBLING NOTES.
We’ve done it! The poem’s encoded. I think. I need to run it through... Hut Eleven. To test it out.
Very good Sylvia. Be careful.
Yes, ma’am.
Might I accompany? I haven’t had stimulating work like this in a long while.
COCKS PISTOL.
You’1l stay where you are, sir. Off you go, Wren.
EXITS.
We can’t let you into all our secrets. I’m going to have to tie you to your chair again, while we complete our mission.
STARTS TYING SCHWARTZMANN.
I forget. I am the prisoner and you are the guard. The girl is bright. You have many like her?
She’s one of the best. But yes, we have many, many like her. That’s why we’ll win the war.
Perhaps. Why not shoot me now? Your Major Harris will not let me live. I already know too much.
It won’t come to that. We’re not brutes. You’1ll find British prisons better-appointed than your own. I expect most prisoners of war won’t have the luxuries you'd be afforded.
I sense bitterness in your tone, Frau Clarke.
FINISHES TYING.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 123
Do you? Need I remind you, our countries are at war? (BEAT) You’re a ranking officer in German intelligence... I’ve something I must ask...
(BITTER LAUGH) You expect me to share secrets with you simply because we share your... strange-coloured tea.
The Carnation milk turns it orange. (BEAT) You know my name. Do you know of an agent who shares it?
Clarke?
My husband. Henry Clarke.
This is a British agent? Or a double agent? (BEAT) There is a quiver in your ‘stiff upper lip’, I see.
We may be enemies, but we’re still human beings.
You are careful not to chafe with your ropes. Very humane.
(SIGH) Is there a Mrs Schwartzmann?
You think this is my real name? I am a Baron, no less. We have a house in Bremen. My wife. My children. My dogs.
Why are you telling me this?
Because it does not matter. I know nothing of your husband. Officers of the Abwehr barely know one another, let alone the agents they run. Most of all, it does not matter because you will die.
I don’t think so. What the Doctor said about next year... I’m inclined to believe him.
CRISS-CROSS (FINAL) Page 124
Your Doctor said the war would be over. He did not say which Side would win.
RUSHES IN.
(BREATHLESS) It worked, ma’am. The code’s secure. Dr Smith’s
message is enciphered and ready.
